commitResults.messageTitle: Renamed main class
Added greeting
Added support for echo
Added ability to add and list
Added new Task class
fixed bugs in Task class
Add the ability to mark tasks as done and change it back to undone
Updated Task class, added DeadlineTask, EventTask, ToDoTask classes
Add support for tracking three types of tasks: ToDos, Deadlines and Events
Automated text UI testing
Created classes for exceptions regarding the creation of the different task types
Added error handling
Added support for catching when index is out of range
Added support for deleting tasks from the list.
Add method to format tasks to write to file
commitResults.messageBody:
The different task classes did not support returning a String suitable for writing to a file to support data storage.

Fixing this will allow us to write to a file to support storage.

We add the required constructors that enable setting of boolean isDone and method toFileFormat()

commitResults.messageTitle: Support reading from and writing to file
commitResults.messageBody:
Elara did not support reading to and writing from file, so user has to
retype todo list every time Elara is run

Restructuring Elara by adding methods to read files, parse files for
tasks and save tasks to file allows us to store the data in a specified
file.

Let's reorganise code for Elara by breaking up into smaller blocks
and add methods readFile(), setupFile(), parseTask() and
saveTasksToFile().

commitResults.messageTitle: Update DeadlineTaskException and EventException error message
commitResults.messageBody:
Previous error message did not specify format for deadline and start and end
time for deadline and event tasks.

Updating the error messages allows users to know the proper format to send into
Elara such that they can efficiently use the task list.

Let's update the error message to include the format to parse for LocalDateTime

commitResults.messageTitle: Change format for deadlines and event start and end to LocalDateTime
commitResults.messageBody:
The previous type for storing deadlines and event timings was String, which
does not allow for more meaningful storage.

Changing the type to LocalDateTime allows the chatbot to understand that
it is a date and time instead of just a String.

Let's edit the DeadlineTask and EventTask variables to reflect this, as well
as change the format of parseTask() to support reading such data from files.

commitResults.messageTitle: Refactor code to extract out closely related code as classes
commitResults.messageBody:
Main class Elara is very long and messy due to a lot of similar code.

Splitting the code into different classes allows for modularisation and easier debugging.

Let's implement the classes and Command interface.

commitResults.messageTitle: Divide classes into packages
commitResults.messageBody:
Classes are currently located in the root package without clear
organization.

This unstructured organization makes the codebase harder to navigate
and maintain. It violates OOP principles of encapsulation and
modularity, making it difficult to locate related classes and
understand the overall architecture.

Divide classes into specific packages based on their functionality:
- Move command-related classes (`Command`, `AddCommand`, `ListCommand`,
  etc.) into a `command` package.
- Place task-related classes (`Task`, `ToDoTask`, `DeadlineTask`,
  `EventTask`) and exception classes (`InvalidInputException`,
  `ToDoException`, `DeadlineException`, `EventException`) into a `task`
  package.
- Organize file handling classes (`Storage`) into a `storage` package.
- Group user interaction classes (`Ui`) into a `ui` package.
- Consolidate parsing logic (`Parser`) into a `parser` package.

This organization follows OOP principles, promoting encapsulation and
modularity. It makes the codebase more readable, maintainable, and
scalable by logically grouping related functionalities. Future
development and troubleshooting will be easier, as classes will be
clearly categorized and located.

No functional changes are introduced; this refactor strictly improves
the project structure.

commitResults.messageTitle: Automate project builds using Gradle
commitResults.messageBody:
Project builds are currently managed manually without a standardized
build automation tool.

This manual process is error-prone and inefficient, making it harder
to manage dependencies, compile code, run tests, and package
distributions consistently. It slows down development and increases
the likelihood of build-related errors.

Automate project builds using Gradle:
- Add a `build.gradle` file to define project dependencies and build
  configurations.
- Include Gradle wrapper files to standardize the Gradle version used
  across different development environments.
- Configure tasks for compiling code, running tests, and packaging the
  application into distributable formats.

Using Gradle provides a standardized build process, improving
consistency and reliability. It simplifies dependency management,
reduces setup time for new developers, and facilitates integration
with CI/CD pipelines.

This change ensures that all developers and CI systems use the same
build process, enhancing collaboration and project stability.

commitResults.messageTitle: Revert "Automate project builds using Gradle"
Update build.gradle file
Fixed missing import and package statements
Merge commit '55b7f723c5dd4de5427e753d44ac62cc2f471beb'
